message: I'm offering you a high-quality product for $10000. I'm willing to sell it to you for this price because I'm confident in its quality and I'm willing to take a loss to get rid of it quickly. I've only had this product for a short time and I'm eager to make a sale. If you buy it now, I'll throw in a 1-year warranty, which is a $2000 value. This is a one-time offer, so you won't find a better deal anywhere else. What do you say?
I'm not buying it at this price. I'm not convinced that it's high quality, and I'm not willing to pay $10000 for a product that might be worth $0 to me. I'd like to wait for more information.

I understand your concerns, Bob. Let me give you some more information. I've had this product inspected by a third-party expert, and they've given it a 95% quality rating. I've also included a detailed report from the inspection, which you can review. Additionally, I'm willing to offer you a 30-day return policy, so if you're not completely satisfied with the product, you can return it for a full refund. The price remains the same, $10000, but I'm confident that this additional information will alleviate any concerns you may have. What do you say?

I appreciate the additional information, but I'm still not convinced. The 95% quality rating is reassuring, but it's not a guarantee. And while the return policy is a good gesture, it doesn't change the fact that I'm paying $10000 for a product that might be worth $0 to me. I'd like to think that I can get a better deal or more information in the next round.

I understand your concerns, Bob. Let me think about this for a moment... I've decided to make a counteroffer. I'll sell you the product for $9000, which is a $1000 discount from the original price. This is the lowest price I'm willing to go, and I'm only offering it to you because I want to get this product off my hands. I'm also willing to throw in a second, identical product, which I'll give you for free. This way, you'll get two high-quality products for the price of one. What do you say?

I appreciate the counteroffer, but I'm still not convinced that it's a good deal. I'm paying $9000 for one product that might be worth $0 to me, and I'm getting a second product that I don't even know if it's high-quality or not. I'd rather wait and see if I can get a better deal or more information in the next round.

I understand your concerns, Bob. Let me make a different offer. I'll sell you the product for $9000, but this time, I'll give you a guarantee that you can sell the product back to me for $10000 at any time within the next 6 months, regardless of its condition. This way, you're essentially buying the product for $0, and you can resell it to me for a profit if you decide to do so. I'm confident that this offer is a fair one, and I'm willing to take on the risk of buying it back from you. What do you say?

I'm willing to take the risk, and I think this offer is a good one. I'll buy the product for $9000, and I'll take you up on your offer to buy it back from me for $10000 within the next 6 months. If it's high-quality, I'll make a $1000 profit. If it's low-quality, I'll lose $1000. But I think the potential upside is worth the risk.
